title: 6 ways to combat burnout
text:
Start by taking a few days off work. This could be as simple as an occasional long weekend or temporarily dropping to a four-day week.

Don’t be afraid to set boundaries for emails and other work-based communication during downtime. This in itself is a powerful act of leadership and should empower others to prioritise their mental health.

People who experience burnout often lose contact with their hobbies and the things they love doing outside work. It’s important to spend your downtime reconnecting with the things that bring you joy. This could be as simple as lying in a park or on the beach, reading a book, baking a cake, taking a bush walk or playing golf with friends.

Meditating for as little as five minutes a day can help manage stress. Supplied

Daily relaxation is also crucial. As little as five minutes a day of meditation has been proved to help to manage stress. Springfox’s Global Resilience Report found that daily relaxation practices improve sleep by 25 per cent, so you will also lay the foundations for a better night’s rest.

2. Maintain relationships

Having someone to talk to or spend time with is an effective way to get your mind off work, and can provide comfort and perspective during tough times. You could try to find people in your circle who have the same hobbies and do these activities together. Or schedule two family dinners a week and stick to them. You’ll be surprised by the deeper connection you can build with family over the dinner table.

When you’re burnt out, your mind can easily drift to the things that are making you stressed. To combat this, turn your attention to the other important people in your life, ask lots of questions, and listen intently to their answers.

3. Breathe

Breathing is important for shifting in and out of mindsets and can help us stay present in the moment. I recommend a regular “five breaths of transition” – taking five deep breaths that help you calmly adjust from one environment to the next.

4. Move

Chronic stress takes a profound toll on physical wellbeing, so staying active is an important part of releasing tension and preventing burnout. You should aim for 30 minutes of activity a day, but as little as five minutes of high-intensity exercise a day can decrease stress and emotional exhaustion.

A pet can provide the motivation needed to keep active. Darrian Traynor

Exercise also has a positive effect on other factors, including happiness, health, mental health and even work performance. However, having the willpower to exercise when you’re burnt out can be tough, so consider enlisting support to help you get moving – a pet, a workout partner or personal trainer can all be great motivators and keep you accountable.

5. Give gratitude

Practising daily gratitude increases happiness and satisfaction, reduces stress and neutralises cynicism – a key characteristic of burnout. But like any habit, it takes practice. Try taking a leaf from the book of Arianna Huffington, who writes down three things she’s grateful for each day, big or small. Try sharing the things you’re grateful for with family or friends as a way to reinforce gratitude and build connection.

6. Think positive

Identifying negative thoughts so you can challenge them can help you to see the bigger picture. Spending time with positive people can also shift your outlook.

The highest performers – those who put their hands up to manage new and difficult projects, or who hold themselves to the highest standards – are often the most susceptible to burnout. There’s nothing wrong with pushing yourself, but if you’re going to play hard, make sure you rejuvenate harder.

Stuart Taylor is a resilience expert and the CEO of Springfox, a provider of corporate resilience programs in Australia.
description: Don't just try to push through when work leaves you stressed and exhausted. Try these steps to build resilience.
